articles.headline: Exercise Your Brain, or Else You’ll ... Uh ...
articles.snippet: The fear of a decaying brain has inspired a mini-industry of products from dietary supplements to computer games.
articles.abstract: The fear of a decaying brain has inspired a mini-industry of products from dietary supplements to computer games.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When David Bunnell, a magazine publisher who lives in Berkeley, Calif., went to a FedEx store to send a package a few years ago, he suddenly drew a blank as he was filling out the forms.

articles.headline: Mortgage-Free, but Not Free From the Temptation to Borrow
articles.snippet: For those people who own their homes mortgage-free, the question is what to do with a houseful of equity.
articles.abstract: For those people who own their homes mortgage-free, the question is what to do with a houseful of equity.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a story about the other homeowners. Not the ones who are having trouble making their mortgage payments and getting all the attention lately. No, this is about the homeowners who do not owe any money on their primary residences because they have paid off their loans.

articles.headline: Higher Offer by Microsoft Brings Yahoo to Table
articles.snippet: The companies are in active merger talks, people involved said, and Microsoft is said to have increased its offer.
articles.abstract: The companies are in active merger talks, people involved said, and Microsoft is said to have increased its offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a three-month standoff, Microsoft was in active merger talks with Yahoo on Friday, several people involved in the discussions said.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: After Hiatus, States Set Wave of Executions
articles.snippet: Less than three weeks after a Supreme Court ruling ended a moratorium on lethal injections, at least 14 execution dates have been set for the coming months.
articles.abstract: Less than three weeks after a Supreme Court ruling ended a moratorium on lethal injections, at least 14 execution dates have been set for the coming months.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  Here in the nation’s leading death-penalty state, and some of the 35 others with capital punishment, execution dockets are quickly filling up.

articles.headline: 20,000 Jobs Lost in 4th Month of Decline
articles.snippet: Many economists took the losses as powerful evidence of a recession, but the cuts’ limited scope raised hopes that a slump would be mild.
articles.abstract: Many economists took the losses as powerful evidence of a recession, but the cuts’ limited scope raised hopes that a slump would be mild.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy lost 20,000 jobs in April, the fourth consecutive month of decline, in what many economists took as powerful evidence that the United States is almost certainly now ensnared in a recession.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: No Budging Is Detected in Bidding for Newsday
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch and Mortimer B. Zuckerman have not signaled they would increase their bid for Newsday to match a higher offer from Cablevision.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch and Mortimer B. Zuckerman have not signaled they would increase their bid for Newsday to match a higher offer from Cablevision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch does not plan to raise his bid for Newsday in an attempt to match a higher offer from Cablevision, while Mortimer B. Zuckerman has not signaled whether he will increase his offer, people involved in the talks said on Friday.

articles.headline: An Upstart Up Against a Jewel
articles.snippet: “The Takeaway,” a brand-new show broadcast on 15 public radio stations, is gearing up to face off with the mother of all public radio shows, “Morning Edition.”
articles.abstract: “The Takeaway,” a brand-new show broadcast on 15 public radio stations, is gearing up to face off with the mother of all public radio shows, “Morning Edition.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Just before 6 a.m. on Tuesday, in a spacious but dilapidated studio belonging to WNYC in New York, a veteran public radio broadcaster named John Hockenberry put down his pages of notes, raised two fists to the sky, and shouted something that only he and his co-host, Adaora Udoji, could hear.

articles.headline: A Last Vanishing Act for Robert Vesco, Fugitive
articles.snippet: Mr. Vesco, who spent most of his life eluding American justice, died in Cuba last year, people close to him said.
articles.abstract: Mr. Vesco, who spent most of his life eluding American justice, died in Cuba last year, people close to him said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA  Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier who spent most of his life eluding American justice, might even have managed to die on the sly.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and Jonathan Kandell

articles.headline: Israel’s Tactics Thwart Attacks, With Trade-Off
articles.snippet: The Israeli military’s nightly arrests and sometimes deadly West Bank raids are at odds with a peace effort that envisions a separate Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: The Israeli military’s nightly arrests and sometimes deadly West Bank raids are at odds with a peace effort that envisions a separate Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: NETANYA, Israel  Suicide bombings in Israel have dropped off so significantly that the nation’s security officials now dare to speak openly of success. But the very steps they are taking to thwart bombers appear to collide head-on with the government’s agenda of achieving peace with the Palestinians.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks New Curbs on Credit-Card Practices
articles.snippet: The rules are aimed at making it more difficult for credit card companies to raise rates arbitrarily, conceal high penalty fees, or engage in other practices that consumer groups say are abusive.
articles.abstract: The rules are aimed at making it more difficult for credit card companies to raise rates arbitrarily, conceal high penalty fees, or engage in other practices that consumer groups say are abusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal bank regulators on Friday proposed a new set of rules to make it more difficult for credit card companies to raise rates arbitrarily, conceal high penalty fees or engage in other practices that consumer groups say are abusive.

articles.headline: On Sunday TV, One Hot Race Fuels Another
articles.snippet: Tim Russert and George Stephanopoulos plan competing interviews of the Democratic candidates on Sunday.
articles.abstract: Tim Russert and George Stephanopoulos plan competing interviews of the Democratic candidates on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It will be a generational battle royal, the younger upstart against the more seasoned warrior who resents the challenge.

articles.headline: Prepping Robots to Perform Surgery
articles.snippet: From knees to the heart, more operations are being performed by robots, under the guidance of surgeons.
articles.abstract: From knees to the heart, more operations are being performed by robots, under the guidance of surgeons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT do you call a surgeon who operates without scalpels, stitching tools or a powerful headlamp to light the patient’s insides? A better doctor, according to a growing number of surgeons who prefer to hand over much of the blood-and-guts portion of their work to medical robots controlled from computer consoles.

articles.headline: Turkish Schools Offer Pakistan a Gentler Vision of Islam
articles.snippet: Turkish educators are offering an alternative approach to religious schools that could reduce extremists’ influence.
articles.abstract: Turkish educators are offering an alternative approach to religious schools that could reduce extremists’ influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan  Praying in Pakistan has not been easy for Mesut Kacmaz, a Muslim teacher from Turkey.

articles.headline: For Democrats, Instincts Differ on Economics
articles.snippet: The candidates have taken different approaches to the gas tax, the mortgage crisis and retirement savings.
articles.abstract: The candidates have taken different approaches to the gas tax, the mortgage crisis and retirement savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they traveled across Indiana and North Carolina over the last few days, trading charges and countercharges about the wisdom of suspending the federal gas tax for the summer, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama were really having a larger fight.

articles.headline: Even the Insured Feel Strain of Health Costs
articles.snippet: For millions of people with employer health insurance, premiums and co-payments have increased quickly while coverage has become less extensive.
articles.abstract: For millions of people with employer health insurance, premiums and co-payments have increased quickly while coverage has become less extensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic slowdown has swelled the ranks of people without health insurance. But now it is also threatening millions of people who have insurance but find that the coverage is too limited or that they cannot afford their own share of medical costs.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Milt Freudenheim

articles.headline: ’88 Campaign Offers a Lesson in Using Symbols as Bludgeons
articles.snippet: Memories of Republican challenges to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis’s patriotism haunt many Democrats.
articles.abstract: Memories of Republican challenges to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis’s patriotism haunt many Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Sometimes, as Senator Barack Obama seemed to argue earlier this year, a flag pin is just a flag pin.

articles.headline: How to Clear a Road to Redemption
articles.snippet: The auction-rate securities mess is another illustration of damaging conflicts of interest at the nation’s big brokerage firms.
articles.abstract: The auction-rate securities mess is another illustration of damaging conflicts of interest at the nation’s big brokerage firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT is Day 79 in the hostage crisis otherwise known as the auction-rate securities market. Some $300 billion worth of investors’ funds  advertised as being easy as pie to cash in  are still locked up. And the brokerage firms that got investors into this mess are doing little to help.

articles.headline: Microsoft Withdraws Bid for Yahoo
articles.snippet: Microsoft said it was abandoning its bid after it raised its offer by $5 billion but Yahoo rejected it as still too low.
articles.abstract: Microsoft said it was abandoning its bid after it raised its offer by $5 billion but Yahoo rejected it as still too low.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said Saturday that it was abandoning its blockbuster bid to acquire Yahoo after it raised its offer by $5 billion but Yahoo rejected it as still too low.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: A Lender Gets Caught in the Currents
articles.snippet: The story of CIT illustrates the perils awaiting any firm that jumps into seemingly lucrative new arenas at the expense of focusing on markets that it knows and understands best.
articles.abstract: The story of CIT illustrates the perils awaiting any firm that jumps into seemingly lucrative new arenas at the expense of focusing on markets that it knows and understands best.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALKING across his sun-drenched office overlooking Fifth Avenue and the New York Public Library, Jeffrey M. Peek points to a picture on his desk. It is a perfect family portrait, filled with smiling, happy faces on a mountain summit. Perfect, except for one detail: there’s a problem with the guy in the far left corner.

articles.headline: How Much for Those Baby Photos?
articles.snippet: Can a few snapshots of a baby or a bride, accompanied by a fawning article, really be worth millions of dollars? In the competitive world of celebrity magazines, they just might be.
articles.abstract: Can a few snapshots of a baby or a bride, accompanied by a fawning article, really be worth millions of dollars? In the competitive world of celebrity magazines, they just might be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, when a magazine paid a celebrity more than a person might earn in a lifetime in return for a set of pictures, media critics questioned the ethics of both the publication and the star.

articles.headline: Publisher Tested the Waters Online, Then Dove In
articles.snippet: The niche publisher I.D.G. has been working out the answers to some big mainstream questions. The biggest: Can print media survive the transition to the Internet?
articles.abstract: The niche publisher I.D.G. has been working out the answers to some big mainstream questions. The biggest: Can print media survive the transition to the Internet?
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be a niche publisher, but the International Data Group has been working out the answers to some big mainstream questions. The biggest one: Can print media survive the transition to the Internet?

articles.headline: Government Intensifies Mortgage Investigation
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. and the I.R.S. are said to be investigating whether some mortgage lenders turned a blind eye when prospective borrowers used inflated income figures.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. and the I.R.S. are said to be investigating whether some mortgage lenders turned a blind eye when prospective borrowers used inflated income figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal agencies are intensifying a criminal investigation of the mortgage industry and focusing on whether some lenders turned a blind eye to inflated income figures provided by borrowers.

articles.headline: After Deal Dies, Yahoo Weighs Its Next Move
articles.snippet: As Yahoo investors wait to see how far their shares will fall after Microsoft withdrew its offer, a Google partnership is being considered as a lifeline.
articles.abstract: As Yahoo investors wait to see how far their shares will fall after Microsoft withdrew its offer, a Google partnership is being considered as a lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  How low will Yahoo’s stock go on Monday? And how long will it stay there?

articles.headline: Microsoft’s Failed Yahoo Bid Risks Online Growth
articles.snippet: Without a Yahoo deal, Microsoft faces a problem: its time-tested recipe for success isn’t working against Google.
articles.abstract: Without a Yahoo deal, Microsoft faces a problem: its time-tested recipe for success isn’t working against Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, walked away from a Yahoo deal on Saturday still looking for an answer to his company’s fundamental problem: its time-tested recipe for success isn’t working against Google, the leader in the current wave of Internet computing.

articles.headline: Seeing Grit and Ruthlessness in Clinton’s Love of the Fight
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton has cast herself as a warrior, but her pugilistic imagery also evokes her political baggage.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has cast herself as a warrior, but her pugilistic imagery also evokes her political baggage.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is waving her fists across Indiana, signing autographs on boxing gloves.
articles.byline: By Mark Leibovich and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Hezbollah Trains Iraqis in Iran, Officials Say
articles.snippet: A U.S. official said the account of Hezbollah’s role was provided by militia members who were captured in Iraq.
articles.abstract: A U.S. official said the account of Hezbollah’s role was provided by militia members who were captured in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Militants from the Lebanese group Hezbollah have been training Iraqi militia fighters at a camp near Tehran, according to American interrogation reports that the United States has supplied to the Iraqi government.

articles.headline: Steve Jobs Stakes Out the TV Den
articles.snippet: A lot of us carry a little bit of Steve Jobs around in our pocket, in the form of iPods and iPhones. Now, Apple is after the remaining bit of life-share that it doesn’t already own, the home front.
articles.abstract: A lot of us carry a little bit of Steve Jobs around in our pocket, in the form of iPods and iPhones. Now, Apple is after the remaining bit of life-share that it doesn’t already own, the home front.
articles.lead_paragraph: I don’t own my iPod. It owns me.

articles.headline: In Poll, Obama Survives Furor, but Fall Is the Test
articles.snippet: A majority of voters say the controversy over Barack Obama’s ex-pastor has not affected their opinion, but many say it could sway voters in November.
articles.abstract: A majority of voters say the controversy over Barack Obama’s ex-pastor has not affected their opinion, but many say it could sway voters in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A majority of American voters say that the furor over the relationship between Senator Barack Obama and his former pastor has not affected their opinion of Mr. Obama, but a substantial number say that it could influence voters this fall should he be the Democratic presidential nominee, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Marjorie Connelly
